clusters.title: ‘I don’t know how we would survive’: caregivers speak of fears over upcoming Medicaid cuts
clusters.neutral_headline: Caregivers fear Medicaid cuts in the United States

items.title: ‘I don’t know how we would survive’: caregivers speak of fears over upcoming Medicaid cuts
items.standfirst: Program covers low-income families, but families brace for cuts to it as part of the Trump-backed ‘one big, beautiful bill’Whether taking care of an older parent, a relative with disabilities or a child with a serious medical condition, family caregivers in the US are nervous and afraid of upcoming cuts to Medicaid – including those resulting from the Donald Trump-backed legislation known as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.The program, which serves low-income families, pregnant women, children, seniors and people with disabilities, enables more than 70 million people to receive critical services while alleviating some of the financial demands on caregivers. But now the bill could chip away at that support with cuts that include ending the temporary incentive for states to adopt the Medicaid expansion, implementing mandatory work requirements (with some exceptions), more frequent eligibility redeterminations for those covered under the Medicaid expansion, and reducing state funding that could force cuts to state-funded home and community-based services for older adults. Continue reading...
items.content: Program covers low-income families, but families brace for cuts to it as part of the Trump-backed ‘one big, beautiful bill’Whether taking care of an older parent, a relative with disabilities or a child with a serious medical condition, family caregivers in the US are nervous and afraid of upcoming cuts to Medicaid – including those resulting from the Donald Trump-backed legislation known as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.The program, which serves low-income families, pregnant women, children, seniors and people with disabilities, enables more than 70 million people to receive critical services while alleviating some of the financial demands on caregivers. But now the bill could chip away at that support with cuts that include ending the temporary incentive for states to adopt the Medicaid expansion, implementing mandatory work requirements (with some exceptions), more frequent eligibility redeterminations for those covered under the Medicaid expansion, and reducing state funding that could force cuts to state-funded home and community-based services for older adults. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Caregivers express concerns about potential cuts to Medicaid programs.
The cuts are part of the Trump-backed "One Big Beautiful Bill" legislation.
Medicaid provides services to low-income families, seniors, and those with disabilities.
The bill could end incentives for states to expand Medicaid coverage.
Proposed cuts include work requirements and redeterminations for Medicaid recipients.

clusters.title: It’s not too late: the House of Lords can still protect disabled people from this dangerous assisted dying bill | Lucy Webster
clusters.neutral_headline: House of Lords can protect disabled people from assisted dying bill

items.title: It’s not too late: the House of Lords can still protect disabled people from this dangerous assisted dying bill | Lucy Webster
items.standfirst: MPs passed it without sufficient safeguarding. If there is any point to the upper chamber, it is to give the legislation the open debate we needSign up for our new weekly newsletter Matters of Opinion, where our columnists and writers will reflect on what they’ve been debating, thinking about, reading and moreThe House of Lords has a rare opportunity to prove its worth to the country today, as it begins to debate the assisted dying bill. Personally, I would be in favour of peers throwing out the whole idea, which is what this dangerous and badly written bill surely deserves. But it is unlikely that they will want to go so directly against the Commons, especially on such a controversial issue. So instead I must hope that they listen to disabled people’s groups, as well as legal and medical experts, and at least undo some of the lower house’s most egregious errors.Whether you are for or against the principle of assisted dying (I am pro), we should be able to agree that the passage of this particular bill through the Commons has been haphazard, deeply unedifying and fundamentally flawed. The Lords should reject this precedent and, by adopting a better process, produce a much safer bill than the one they have been sent.Lucy Webster is a political journalist and the author of The View from Down Here: Life As a Young Disabled Woman Continue reading...
items.content: MPs passed it without sufficient safeguarding. If there is any point to the upper chamber, it is to give the legislation the open debate we needSign up for our new weekly newsletter Matters of Opinion, where our columnists and writers will reflect on what they’ve been debating, thinking about, reading and moreThe House of Lords has a rare opportunity to prove its worth to the country today, as it begins to debate the assisted dying bill. Personally, I would be in favour of peers throwing out the whole idea, which is what this dangerous and badly written bill surely deserves. But it is unlikely that they will want to go so directly against the Commons, especially on such a controversial issue. So instead I must hope that they listen to disabled people’s groups, as well as legal and medical experts, and at least undo some of the lower house’s most egregious errors.Whether you are for or against the principle of assisted dying (I am pro), we should be able to agree that the passage of this particular bill through the Commons has been haphazard, deeply unedifying and fundamentally flawed. The Lords should reject this precedent and, by adopting a better process, produce a much safer bill than the one they have been sent.Lucy Webster is a political journalist and the author of The View from Down Here: Life As a Young Disabled Woman Continue reading...

ai_summary: The House of Lords is debating the assisted dying bill.
The author hopes the Lords will address errors in the bill.
The author suggests the Lords listen to disabled people's groups.
The author believes the bill's passage through the Commons was flawed.
The author supports a safer bill than the one sent by the Commons.

items.standfirst: Research finds children as young as nine in England and Wales taken to A&E because of lack of specialist suitesChildren as young as nine detained under the Mental Health Act are spending hours in NHS accident and emergency departments under police control rather than in specialist mental health assessment suites.The detention under the act of children in England and Wales in police cells was banned in 2017 but a lack of suitable options has led to the use of A&E departments. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Experience: my babies were born seven weeks apart
clusters.neutral_headline: Experience: my babies were born seven weeks apart

items.title: Experience: my babies were born seven weeks apart
items.standfirst: After years of miscarriages, I had abandoned the prospect of giving birth. Then, as we prepared to conceive using a surrogate, the impossible happenedThe first time I miscarried, I blamed myself. After getting pregnant early on in our relationship, at 34, I had a flash of doubt that my partner Alex and I weren’t ready to be parents. Then, a few weeks later, the pregnancy was over.My second early loss, just a few months later, hit me harder. We went to a fertility specialist, and the tests on both of us came back clear, but then I couldn’t get pregnant at all. Continue reading...
items.content: After years of miscarriages, I had abandoned the prospect of giving birth. Then, as we prepared to conceive using a surrogate, the impossible happenedThe first time I miscarried, I blamed myself. After getting pregnant early on in our relationship, at 34, I had a flash of doubt that my partner Alex and I weren’t ready to be parents. Then, a few weeks later, the pregnancy was over.My second early loss, just a few months later, hit me harder. We went to a fertility specialist, and the tests on both of us came back clear, but then I couldn’t get pregnant at all. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Does my vagina really need a ‘facial’?
clusters.neutral_headline: Does my vagina really need a ‘facial’?

items.title: Does my vagina really need a ‘facial’?
items.standfirst: The idea that your vagina should smell as fresh as a daisy or look like a doll’s is an insult to your humanity and a hazard to your healthHi Ugly,I have been noticing a barrage of ads for “vaginal wellness” products: suppositories, balms and serums, and even a “vagi facial” at a local spa. What’s up with this? I was always taught that my vagina was self-cleaning and beautiful. Suddenly I am not so sure, and even find myself wondering if my labia are “normal” or in fact gross. Is this really happening?Why is this column called ‘Ask Ugly’?My father had plastic surgery. Now he wants me and my mother to get work doneHow should I be styling my pubic hair?How do I deal with imperfection?I want to ignore beauty culture. But I’ll never get anywhere if I don’t look a certain way Continue reading...

What’s up with this? I was always taught that my vagina was self-cleaning and beautiful. Suddenly I am not so sure, and even find myself wondering if my labia are “normal” or in fact gross. clusters.title: Clean air must be made a global priority | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Clean air must be made a global priority

items.title: Clean air must be made a global priority | Letter
items.standfirst: Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening millions of lives and harming health, says Jane BurstonYour article (Millions of Britons face higher risk of heart failure due to dirty air, study suggests, 8 September) is just the latest reminder that toxic air is a public health crisis. The evidence is piling up. There’s also fresh evidence that air pollution can drive devastating forms of dementia.Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening lives and worsening health everywhere. But the good news is that solutions are at hand. Academics at Princeton University have recently shown that cutting pollution in the US could save thousands of lives each year. Continue reading...

The evidence is piling up. There’s also fresh evidence that air pollution can drive devastating forms of dementia.Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening lives and worsening health everywhere. But the good news is that solutions are at hand. Academics at Princeton University have recently shown that cutting pollution in the US could save thousands of lives each year. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Striking tube drivers have proved a point | Brief letters

items.title: Striking tube drivers have proved a point | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Chaos on London roads | Smiling drivers | Samantha Cameron’s trading woes | Banksy’s gavel | A harsh recoveryAnyone caught in the chaos of the mad, traffic-infested streets in London as they tried to get home during the strike by RMT tube drivers might realise how important those drivers are in keeping London running smoothly (Report, 8 September). Perhaps it’s worth paying them more and reducing their working hours.Dr Alan LaffertyLondon• Regarding the letter on smiling (Letters, 10 September), I am told by my son that no one gives way to another vehicle in the south. While this is possibly a wild generalisation, I find that letting a vehicle into a queue of traffic in front of you changes a stressed face to a smile of thanks.Jeanette HamiltonBuxton, Derbyshire Continue reading...

Perhaps it’s worth paying them more and reducing their working hours.Dr Alan LaffertyLondon• Regarding the letter on smiling (Letters, 10 September), I am told by my son that no one gives way to another vehicle in the south. While this is possibly a wild generalisation, I find that letting a vehicle into a queue of traffic in front of you changes a stressed face to a smile of thanks.Jeanette HamiltonBuxton, Derbyshire Continue reading...

clusters.title: Michel Odent obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Michel Odent Obituary: Obstetrician Championed Natural Childbirth

items.title: Michel Odent obituary
items.standfirst: Obstetrician whose work in a French hospital and then in London led to a revolution in how mothers are treated in labourThe pioneering French obstetrician Michel Odent, who has died aged 95, spent more than 50 years passionately promoting understanding of the natural physiology of childbirth. From the 1960s onwards, “active management of labour”, using artificial oxytocin and other techniques, had dominated obstetric practice. Odent’s work flagged up its pitfalls, and offered an alternative view.Daniela Drandić of the International Confederation of Midwives said: “In the 1970s birth was institutionalised and medicalised. Michel Odent reminded us that physiological processes during pregnancy and birth should be respected, which was very important as things had gone too far in the other direction. There wasn’t much discourse at the time and he showed us another way.” Continue reading...
items.content: Obstetrician whose work in a French hospital and then in London led to a revolution in how mothers are treated in labourThe pioneering French obstetrician Michel Odent, who has died aged 95, spent more than 50 years passionately promoting understanding of the natural physiology of childbirth. From the 1960s onwards, “active management of labour”, using artificial oxytocin and other techniques, had dominated obstetric practice. Odent’s work flagged up its pitfalls, and offered an alternative view.Daniela Drandić of the International Confederation of Midwives said: “In the 1970s birth was institutionalised and medicalised. Michel Odent reminded us that physiological processes during pregnancy and birth should be respected, which was very important as things had gone too far in the other direction. There wasn’t much discourse at the time and he showed us another way.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Michel Odent, a pioneering obstetrician, has died at the age of 95.
He advocated for understanding the natural physiology of childbirth.
Odent challenged the dominance of "active management of labour" practices.
He highlighted the pitfalls of using artificial oxytocin and other techniques.
His work emphasized respecting physiological processes during pregnancy and birth.

clusters.title: GMC examines doctor’s Reform speech linking vaccines to royal family cancer
clusters.neutral_headline: GMC Examines Doctor's Speech Linking Vaccines to Royal Family Cancer

items.title: GMC examines doctor’s Reform speech linking vaccines to royal family cancer
items.standfirst: Medical bodies and prime minister condemn Aseem Malhotra’s ‘pseudo-science’ remarks at party conferenceThe General Medical Council is examining comments by a controversial doctor who used a speech at Reform UK’s conference to link Covid vaccines to cancer in the royal family, amid mounting condemnation of him by senior medics.The regulator, which is charged with upholding professional standards in UK medicine, is also progressing with an investigation into Aseem Malhotra, currently an adviser to Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy, over a previous claim. It may consider whether to stop or limit his ability to work as a doctor in the UK in the interests of protecting the public. Continue reading...
items.content: Medical bodies and prime minister condemn Aseem Malhotra’s ‘pseudo-science’ remarks at party conferenceThe General Medical Council is examining comments by a controversial doctor who used a speech at Reform UK’s conference to link Covid vaccines to cancer in the royal family, amid mounting condemnation of him by senior medics.The regulator, which is charged with upholding professional standards in UK medicine, is also progressing with an investigation into Aseem Malhotra, currently an adviser to Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy, over a previous claim. It may consider whether to stop or limit his ability to work as a doctor in the UK in the interests of protecting the public. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The General Medical Council is reviewing comments made by Dr. Aseem Malhotra.
Malhotra linked COVID vaccines to cancer in the royal family during a speech.
Medical bodies and the prime minister have condemned his remarks as "pseudo-science."
The GMC is also investigating Malhotra over a previous claim.
The GMC may restrict his ability to practice medicine in the UK.

clusters.title: ‘The chaos is the point’: tumult as Covid vaccine boosters deployed under RFK Jr
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘The chaos is the point’: tumult as Covid vaccine boosters deployed under RFK Jr: People attempting to obtain vaccine report major hurdles amid new limitations brought in by Trump health secretary

items.title: ‘The chaos is the point’: tumult as Covid vaccine boosters deployed under RFK Jr
items.standfirst: People attempting to obtain vaccine report major hurdles amid new limitations brought in by Trump health secretaryThe first deployment of updated Covid shots under the Trump administration has been plagued by access issues and misinformation amid confusion and chaos at US health agencies.People attempting to get the vaccines say they have struggled to understand eligibility requirements, book appointments, process insurance claims, battle misinformation from pharmacists and obtain prescriptions from their doctors in some states. Such hurdles will disproportionately affect people of color and low-income people, experts say. Continue reading...
items.content: People attempting to obtain vaccine report major hurdles amid new limitations brought in by Trump health secretaryThe first deployment of updated Covid shots under the Trump administration has been plagued by access issues and misinformation amid confusion and chaos at US health agencies.People attempting to get the vaccines say they have struggled to understand eligibility requirements, book appointments, process insurance claims, battle misinformation from pharmacists and obtain prescriptions from their doctors in some states. Such hurdles will disproportionately affect people of color and low-income people, experts say. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The rollout of updated COVID shots faces access issues and misinformation.
People report difficulties understanding eligibility and booking appointments.
Insurance claims, misinformation, and prescriptions are causing problems.
These hurdles disproportionately affect people of color and low-income individuals.
The new limitations were brought in by the Trump health secretary.
